title-group.article-title: Inter-Industry Leverage Differences and the DeAngelo-Masulis Tax Shield Hypothesis

abstract.p: Recent theoretical developments regarding the optimal capital structure for a firm suggest that observed differences in financial leverage among firms may be attributed to the total tax shelter characteristics of each firm. DeAngelo and Masulis demonstrated in their 1980 paper that a firm's use of debt should be inversely related to the portion of income sheltered by non-debt tax shelds such as depreciation and investment tax credits. They summarized some aggregated empirical evidence showing that tax shelters and leverage both vary across industries, thus lending support to their thesis. However, the authors of this paper show that the hypothesized inverse relationship between interest-bearing debt ratios and non-debt tax shelters does not arise at either the industry level or the firm level. Since these results are directly counter to the cross-sectional version of the DeAngelo-Masulis thesis, it is clear that more theoretical and empirical research is needed in this important area.
